III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Sufficiency of staff.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 07/12/2024, youth was assaulted outside on facility grounds by
five other youth, names unknown. This occurred in an area that
does not have video camera coverage. It is unknown where staff
were when this occurred. Youth has injuries to his face as a result
of the assault. Youth has an observable fat lip and a cut on his
head. On 07/15/2024, youth was located in Grand Rapids and
staff do not want to pick up youth.
Investigation Phone messages were left with Complainant on July 17, July
23, August 1, and August 12, 2024, with no return phone call.
2

DHHS Worker also left multiple phone messages with no return
call.
Director was interviewed face to face at the facility on July 18,
2024, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Director reported
Youth A has been at the facility since June 15, 2024, and should
know the youths’ names that attacked him. Director denied being
aware of any incident when Youth A was attacked by other youth
in the program. Director stated Youth A went AWOL July 11, 12,
and 14 and did not recall Youth A having any marks or bruises on
his face or neck. Director reported there was not any medical
documentation of Youth A being assaulted and having injuries or
an incident report of Youth A being assaulted by his peers.
Director stated she was notified on July 15, 2024, at 10:35pm by
Child Protective Services (CPS) in Grand Rapids that Youth A
was at the Grand Rapids Police Department and CPS would be
returning Youth A to the facility. Director reported Youth A
returned to the facility on July 16, 2024, at 2:55am by Child
Protective Services. Director denied refusing to pick up Youth A
from Grand Rapids. Director stated generally the police or CPS
bring a youth back to the facility when the youth is located after
going AWOL. Director reported if requested the facility would
have brought Youth A back from Grand Rapids but reported they
were not asked to pick up Youth A.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on July 18,
2024, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth A was not
observed to have any marks or bruises on his face or neck area.
Youth A reported he has been at the facility for about a month and
often runs away to “get the fuck away from here.” Youth A
described not feeling safe at the facility because the youth want to
“beat my ass.” Youth A described being hit in the eye from youth
at the facility while outside, across the street in a blind spot from
the camera. Youth A stated he did not know the names of the
youth that hit him and was not sure where staff were when the
incident occurred. Youth A denied telling staff about the incident.
Youth A later in the interview described getting the injuries while
he was AWOL by youth in the community who thought Youth A
was someone else. Youth A could not recall if he told staff about
this incident when he returned from being AWOL. Youth A later
described getting the injuries from Youth C, Youth E, and Youth F
who followed Youth A when he went AWOL and assaulted Youth
A. Youth A reported staff did not see the incident because it
occurred while being AWOL. Youth A denied telling staff about
the assault. Youth A denied going to the doctor and being treated
3

for his injuries. Youth A stated staff follow him and try to talk with
him to convince him not to go AWOL or tell him how dangerous it
can be, but he does not listen to staff. Youth A stated when he
went AWOL, he panhandled to get money for a bus ticket to
Grand Rapids. Youth A described getting enough money and
taking the bus to Grand Rapids. Youth A reported he was picked
up in Grand Rapids, was at the police station then brought back to
the facility.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on July 18,
2024, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth B denied
seeing Youth A with a fat lip or cut on his head while being at the
facility. Youth B stated Youth A does not get into fights at the
facility, although did report Youth A hit Youth B in the face a few
hours prior to the interview. Youth B reported if youth are fighting
staff step in to break it up and separate youth. Youth B reported
when Youth A returns from going AWOL Youth A tells everyone
he went to a crack house to smoke or panhandles and begs to get
money so he can give the money to the homeless to buy Youth A
a vape.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at the facility on July 18,
2024, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth C denied ever
seeing Youth A with a fat lip or cut on his head. Youth C reported
he is in a different program and section of the facility so does not
often interact with Youth A. Youth C denied ever going AWOL
with Youth A. Youth C stated if youth try to fight with one another
staff intervene and separate the youth.
Youth D was interviewed face to face at the facility on July 18,
2024, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth D denied ever
going AWOL with Youth A. Youth D reported a couple days ago
Youth A’s eye was “swollen a little.” Youth D refused to answer
any questions and walked out of the interview room.
Youth E was interviewed face to face at the facility on July 18,
2024, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth E denied ever
seeing Youth A with a fat lip or cut on his head. Youth E stated he
has never gone AWOL with Youth A, but they have gone AWOL
on the same day but at different times. Youth E reported being in
a different program and section of the facility than Youth A so he
does not often interact with Youth A. Youth E denied ever seeing
any of the youth assault Youth A or himself assaulting Youth A.
Youth F was interviewed face to face at a different facility on
July 29, 2024, while DHHS Worker joined via Teams. Youth F
4

described knowing Youth A at his previous placement and stated
Youth A frequently went AWOL. Youth F denied ever going
AWOL with Youth A. Youth F reported he could not recall Youth A
having a fat lip or cuts on his face. Youth F stated he heard Youth
A got beat up by some youth at the previous facility, but Youth F
did not see the fight.
Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on July
18, 2024, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Supervisor
reported not recalling any injuries on Youth A’s face last week.
Supervisor reported when Youth A AWOLs he returns and says
he was jumped but does not come back with injuries. Supervisor
stated Youth A will also tell his peers he did a bunch of drugs
when he was AWOL, but the medical assessment never detects
any drugs. Supervisor reported Youth A will act like he is going to
fight but if the other person shows they are going to fight, Youth A
backs down and leaves.
Staff 1 was interviewed via telephone on July 23, 2024, in
collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 1 reported Youth A goes
AWOL frequently. Staff 1 stated sometimes the other youth
trigger Youth A, or he does not like what staff ask him to do, gets
made and just walks away from the facility. Staff 1 reported staff
redirect Youth A, but he gets upset and just walks off. Staff 1
stated when Youth A goes AWOL, he usually goes by himself.
Staff 1 denied Youth A being in any fights recently at the facility or
being assaulted by other youth. Staff 1 could not recall any time
Youth A had injuries on his face, bruised/fat lip, or cuts.
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on July 23, 2024, in
collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 2 reported he could not
recall Youth A having a fat lip or any cuts on his face. Staff 2
stated Youth A may have had a few scratches one time after
going AWOL when Youth A told everyone he was jumped by
some random kids in the neighborhood. Staff 2 reported Youth A
goes AWOL frequently, especially when he does not get his way
or like what staff is saying. Staff 2 stated when Youth A goes
AWOL, he goes by himself. Staff 2 reported he could not recall a
time another youth has gone AWOL with Youth A. Staff 2
described Youth A getting into one fight with another youth but
there were “no blows, more wrestling one another.” Staff 2 denied
Youth A being assaulted by other youth at the facility.
Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on July 31, 2024, in
collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 3 described Youth A as
being okay with staff, kind of a loner, starting arguments with his
5

peers but walks away from the fights and going AWOL a lot. Staff
3 stated Youth A just got into an altercation with another youth
and got punched in the face causing Youth A’s lip to be injured.
This occurred after the date of the allegation. Staff 3 reported she
did not recall any other incidents Youth A was assaulted by his
peers.
Staff 4 was interviewed via telephone on July 31, 2024, in
collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 4 reported Youth A goes
AWOL frequently. Staff 4 stated Youth A gets mad at some of the
staff if he is not allowed to do what he wants to do. Staff 4
described Youth A reporting he smokes marijuana or goes to
crack houses when he goes AWOL. Staff 4 denied ever seeing
Youth A with a busted lip or cuts to the face. Staff 4 stated Youth
A told her four boys from the community jumped him, but Staff 4
could not recall any marks on Youth A when he returned to the
facility. Staff 4 reported Youth A has been in one fight at the
facility where Youth A got punched in the face. Staff 4 stated she
could not recall Youth A ever being assaulted by a group of peers
at the facility.
Shift Coordinator was interviewed via telephone on July 31,
2024, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Shift Coordinator
described Youth A going AWOL more often than the other youth
at the facility. Shift Coordinator reported Youth A generally goes
AWOL by himself but will try and get the other youth to go with
him. Shift Coordinator stated he could not recall seeing Youth A
with a fat lip or bruises on his face. Shift Coordinator reported
Youth A did say he was jumped by community members when he
went AWOL. Shift Coordinator denied Youth A being assaulted by
any peers in the facility.
Staff 5 was interviewed via telephone on July 31, 2024, in
collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 5 stated it is normal
behavior for Youth A to AWOL. Staff 5 denied seeing any bruises
on Youth A’s face or a fat lip. Staff 5 stated Youth A gets into it
with numerous youth, but it does not lead to fights. Staff 5
reported she was not aware of any of Youth A’s peer assaulting
him or Youth A being jumped in the community while he was
AWOL. Staff 5 stated Youth A goes AWOL by himself, his peers
do not go with him. Staff 5 could not recall if she was working
when Youth A returned to the facility from being pick up in Grand
Rapids after going AWOL.
Staff 6 was interviewed via telephone on July 23, 2024, in
collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 6 described Youth A as
6

being a sneaky youth, picking on his peers but then turns away so
the staff catch the reaction of the peer and not necessarily what
Youth A has done to upset his peer. Staff 6 stated he could not
recall Youth A ever being assaulted by a group of his peers or
from individuals in the community while Youth A was AWOL. Staff
6 reported Youth A goes AWOL frequently but normally goes by
himself as Youth A is a “loner.” Staff 6 denied ever seeing Youth
A with a fat lip or marks/bruises on his face.
Staff 7 was interviewed via telephone on August 1, 2024, in
collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 7 stated Youth A’s
behaviors change daily, sometimes he goes with the flow or other
times doesn’t follow the rules and just tries to leave. Staff 7
reported Youth A frequently goes AWOL but generally it is always
by himself. Staff 7 stated Youth A has gotten into fights with other
youth at the facility but has not been injured in the fights. Staff 7
denied seeing Youth A with a fat lip or marks/bruises on his face.
Staff 7 reported she heard Youth A went AWOL and a group of
kids from community jumped him. Staff 7 stated Youth A told her
this when a group of kids walked by the building and Youth A
pointed at them.
Medical Coordinator was interviewed via telephone on
August 1, 2024, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Medical
Coordinator stated she was working when Youth A returned from
Grand Rapids after being AWOL. Medical Coordinator denied
Youth A had a fat lip, cuts on his face or any injuries when he
returned. Medical Coordinator reported Youth A frequently goes
AWOL and normally goes by himself. Medical Coordinator
described Youth A being involved in one or two physical fights
with a youth for making a sexual comment to the youth. Medical
Coordinator stated she believed Youth A had a bruise under his
eye from that fight but was not certain. Medical Coordinator
denied being aware of Youth A being jumped by community
members when AWOL and being injured.
Tour Observation:
In front of the facility there is nothing obstructing the view from the
camera or staff’s line of sight. One of Youth A’s description of the
assault resulting in a fat lip and cut on the head was in front of the
facility.
Documents Reviewed:
• Wolverine Human Services Critical Incident Reports for
Youth A dated 7/11/24, 7/12/24, 7/13/24, and 7/14/24.
None of the incident reports document Youth A having any
7

injuries after returning from being AWOL. There are no
incident reports from Youth A being assaulted by his peers
at the facility.
• Wolverine Human Services Protocols for staff supervising
clients policy: Policy outlines staff maintaining supervision
coverage and line of sight of all clients hen in direct
supervision of client.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as per youth and staff
interviews, staff were supervising Youth A and tried to redirect
Youth A from going AWOL. Staff, youth, including Youth A,
reported Youth A AWOLs frequently and staff verbally intervene to
try and convince Youth A to stay at the facility. Additionally, there
was no information provided that the facility refused to pick up
Youth A from Grand Rapids.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
